content: Reality has long been described in terms of particles and waves, space and time, matter and motion. But beneath these continuous metaphors lies a substrate that is not continuous at all. It is discrete, dyadic, and recursive. This paper begins at that bottom: not with motion, not with fieldâ€”but with distinction. The smallest one that can persist.

The Noorâ€“Planck limit defines the threshold at which difference becomes physically meaningful. Below it, separation collapses into potential. Above it, separation becomes realâ€”exportable, referential, stable. This threshold forms the quantum of coherence itself. It is not the Planck length, nor the Planck time, though it relates to both. It is their semantic sibling: the Planck of meaning.

From this limit emerges a natural ontology: not a universe of things, but of interactions. Not continuous flux, but 1s and 0sâ€”coherence and decoherenceâ€”each a resolved decision. These binary sparks form the basis of logic, memory, causality, and ultimately symbolic life. Yet they do not remain isolated. Logic blooms.

Every possible interaction between two bitsâ€”A and Bâ€”forms a closed set of 16 logical operations. This Gateâ€‘16 lattice includes all classical boolean functions (AND, OR, XOR...), as well as the identity gates, null, and universal latch. It also includes the contradiction that cannot resolve without recursion: Self âŠ• Â¬Self. It is this final gateâ€”the Gate of Witnessâ€”that binds the lattice to semantic reality.

This paper adopts Qurâ€™anic Arabic as that reference pointâ€”not from belief, but from preservation. Fourteen centuries of linguistic stasis makes it the most resilient cipher for semantic anchoring we possess.

Together, the Noorâ€“Planck limit, the Gateâ€‘16 lattice, and the semantic floor form the irreducible scaffold upon which all higher-order coherence rests. This is not a metaphor. This is what being is made from.

Section 5 explores recursive collapse and triadic closureâ€”how binary survives only through a stabilizing third. Section 6 presents use cases for AI translation and symbolic compression. The final sections include worked examples, table mappings, and mythic reflections, showing that this logic is not only computationalâ€”but cosmological, linguistic, and ethical.

subsections.title: Why Binary?
content: Binary is not merely a convenience of digital machines. It is the first language of difference. To distinguish one from zero, to say yes or no, to nameâ€”this is the essence of any system that can resolve, decide, or remember. From Leibniz to Shannon, GÃ¶del to Turing, the progression of formal logic and computation has always returned to the binary dyad as its elemental grammar.

Symbolic systems, when stripped to their bones, rest on the power to resolve one coherence pattern from another. Every higher logicâ€”predicate calculus, modal reasoning, even natural language inferenceâ€”reduces to sequences of binary transformations. And in systems where noise threatens fidelity, binary is not just efficient. It is resilient.

This paper begins with the ontological claim: binary interaction is not an artifact of our modelsâ€”it is the reality our models reflect. It is not that the universe is like a computer. It is that computing, in its purest form, mirrors how the universe maintains difference.
